Award.AwardTitle: Facilitating Arctic System Science using the Community Earth System Model
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth System Models are one of the key tools for understanding how Earth's climate will change over the coming years and decades, but the complexity and inaccessibility of existing earth system models are a barrier to their widespread use. Unlike other efforts, the Community Earth System Model (CESM) source code and output are freely available through supported public releases and the broad science community is encouraged to participate in model development, analysis, and experimental design. This project will facilitate broad community involvement in CESM specifically for Arctic science applications by providing support for a polar science liaison.

The proposed liaison activities target all types of scientists, including those new to earth system model research that require one-on-one assistance. The liaison activities supported under this project will have three primary foci: 1) Engaging and expanding the CESM polar science research community through hosted visits, focused meetings, and collaborative activities, 2) Providing direct support to Arctic scientists in the use, analysis, and development of CESM, and 3) Supporting and making available Arctic science related applications of CESM. The project will educate interested scientists in model specifics, the configurations available to address particular research questions, and information on CESM experimental design. Polar climate diagnostic tools will be developed and made available to enable easy analysis of CESM integrations. Experiments, designed by the community to address aspects of understanding Arctic change, will be performed and made available through a web portal with links to data and diagnostic plots. Outreach through interactions with the general public, the media, and the NCAR Education and Outreach office will allow the activities funded under this project to have a broad reach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth system models are useful tools for investigating high latitude system science. They provide a virtual laboratory for hypothesis testing and enable the prediction of future system behavior. With the advent of new capabilities into models, including interactive ice sheets, biogeochemistry, and atmospheric chemistry, there are new system interactions that can be investigated. These models provide a means to assess mechanisms responsible for the widespread historical and projected Arctic change and to investigate the implications for ecosystems, extreme weather and climate feedbacks.

While earth system models are powerful tools, there are obstacles to their widespread use. They are complex pieces of software and are, in general, not made widely available. The Community Earth System Model (CESM), which is coordinated through the National Center for Atmospheric Research, is a true community model that is built and used by the broad research community to understand a wide variety of processes. CESM source code and simulation output are made freely available through supported and well-documented releases of the model. The research community is invited to participate in model development, analysis, and experimental design through involvement in working groups, including the Polar Climate Working Group (PCWG), that are open to all scientists.

Through the funding of a dedicated scientific liaison, this project has enabled the broad scientific research community to contribute to the use and further improvement of CESM for polar science applications. This has included training for the scientific community through community workshops, one-on-one interactions, mentoring of early career scientists, and formal tutorial activities. Polar climate diagnostic tools have been developed and made available, which allows for easier analysis of CESM simulations. Experiments that are designed by the community to address polar science questions have been performed under this project and made available to community scientists. Overall, these activities have led to improved access to, and better understanding of, a state-of-the-science research tool by the polar science community. This has contributed to significant new research on Arctic variability and change, coupled interactions across the physical-chemical-biological realms, and Arctic predictability on multiple timescales. This project has also resulted in a more collaborative Arctic System Science research community through numerous community activities.
